questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of progressively worsening joint pain. She has had diffuse, aching pain in her knees, shoulders, and hands bilaterally for the past few months, but the pain has become much more severe in the past few weeks. She also reports night sweats and generalized malaise. On physical examination, radial pulses are weak. There are erythematous nodules over the legs that measure 3–5 cm. Laboratory studies show:


Hematocrit
33.2%


Hemoglobin
10.7 g/dL


Leukocyte count
11,300/mm3



Platelet count
615,000/mm3



Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
94 mm/h


Serum



 C-reactive protein
40 mg/dL (N=0.08–3.1)


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Giant cell arteritis (GCT) is more common in women and can cause malaise, arthralgias, night sweats, decreased peripheral pulses, an elevated ESR, increased CRP, anemia, leukocytosis, and thrombocytosis. However, GCT is almost exclusively seen in patients above the age of 50 years, and cutaneous manifestations are not seen. Instead, patients typically have a history of headache, scalp pain, and jaw claudication because the temporal artery is frequently affected.

B) INCORRECT:

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) can manifest with erythematous nodules, malaise, night sweats, arthralgia, anemia, leukocytosis, and elevated ESR and CRP. However, decreased radial pulsations are typically not present because peripheral vascular disease is a rare manifestation of PAN. Instead, patients usually present with hypertension and/or renal insufficiency (due to renal artery stenosis) and symptoms of neuropathy (e.g., paresthesias, sensory loss, weakness).

C) INCORRECT:

Microscopic polyangiitis can cause malaise, arthralgias, night sweats, skin nodules, anemia, leukocytosis, thrombocytosis, and an elevated ESR and CRP. However, microscopic polyangiitis is usually seen in middle-aged adults. Furthermore, decreased peripheral pulses would not be expected because microscopic polyangiitis predominantly involves small arteries (arterioles). Instead, patients present with features of nephritic syndrome (e.g., hematuria, hypertension) and acute renal failure (e.g., oliguria) as a result of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, or hemoptysis due to alveolar hemorrhage.

D) INCORRECT:

Because thromboangiitis obliterans (TAO) causes endarteritis and occlusion of distal, medium-sized arteries, it could manifest in a young adult with decreased radial pulses. However, TAO is much more common in men, and features such as malaise, night sweats, arthralgia, erythematous nodules, a raised ESR, leukocytosis, and thrombocytosis would not be expected. Instead, a history of smoking, Raynaud phenomenon, and features of superficial thrombophlebitis (cord-like, painful veins) would be present.

E) CORRECT:

Takayasu arteritis is a granulomatous inflammation involving all layers of the walls of large arteries such as the aorta and its major branches. Its incidence peaks at 15–45 years of age and it is more common in women (especially those of Asian ethnicity). In the initial stages of the disease, patients have nonspecific symptoms such as fever, malaise, and/or arthralgia. Eventually, the large arteries narrow, which causes decreased peripheral pulses (so-called pulseless disease). Systemic inflammation causes elevation of ESR, CRP, leukocyte count, and thrombocyte count. In some patients, necrotizing inflammation of medium-sized subcutaneous vessels occurs, which results in erythema nodosum.

See “Overview of large-vessel vasculitides” table.
Image Description:

MRI angiography aorta (A: with contrast; sagittal plane. B: inversion recovery dark blood sequence; axial plane)

The descending aorta shows luminal dilatation and irregularity (A: green overlay), with multiple areas of wall thickening (B: examples indicated by red dimension lines).

These features are characteristic of Takayasu arteritis.
questions.hint: Aortic arteriography of this patient would show areas of thickening and narrowing of the aortic arch.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman who recently emigrated to the USA from Japan comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of night sweats, malaise, and joint pain. During this time, she has also had a 6-kg (13-lb) weight loss. Physical examination shows weak brachial and radial pulses. There are tender subcutaneous nodules on both legs. Carotid bruits are heard on auscultation bilaterally. Laboratory studies show an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 96 mm/h. A CT scan of the chest shows thickening and narrowing of the aortic arch. Microscopic examination of the aortic arch is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Fibrinoid necrosis of the intima and media

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fibrinoid necrosis of the tunica intima and tunica media are characteristic of polyarteritis nodosa (PAN), which can manifest with fever, night sweats, malaise, arthralgia, and erythema nodosum. However, PAN involves small- to medium-sized arteries (e.g., renal arteries, vasa nervorum, arteries supplying the intestines, and cutaneous vessels) rather than large vessels, which are affected in this patient.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a muscle biopsy sample with a medium-sized arterial vessel (H&E stain; low magnification)

There is transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with leukocytic infiltration and fibrinoid necrosis.

These findings are characteristic of polyarteritis nodosa.

B) CORRECT:

The hallmark of Takayasu arteritis (TA) is granulomatous inflammation of the arterial wall affecting the large arteries (typically the aorta and its branches). TA is more common among women with Asian ancestry, and its peak incidence is between 15 and 45 years of age. This condition manifests with systemic features that include fever, malaise, and arthralgia. Other features of TA include decreased brachial and radial pulses (pulseless disease), syncope, carotid bruit, angina pectoris, impaired vision, and Raynaud phenomenon, all of which are due to narrowing of the large arteries. Erythema nodosum and urticaria may also be seen in TA. Microscopic examination of the diseased vessels would show granulomatous inflammation of the vessel walls, with inflammatory cells infiltrating the tunica media and tunica adventitia.

Patients with Takayasu arteritis should be treated with corticosteroids.
Image Description:

Angiography thoracic aorta (left anterior oblique view) of a patient with Takayasu arteritis

Stenoses (examples indicated by white arrows) are seen in the innominate (I), left common carotid (C), and left subclavian (S) arteries. An injection catheter is seen in the dilated ascending aorta (green overlay).

C) INCORRECT:

Subendothelial hyaline deposition is a form of arteriolosclerosis commonly seen in individuals with chronic essential hypertension and/or diabetes. It can also be part of the normal aging process. However, thickening of the aortic arch, erythema nodosum, and the systemic symptoms of night sweats, malaise, joint pain, and weight loss are not associated with hyaline deposits. Furthermore, this patient is 32 years of age and has none of the risk factors for hyaline deposition.

D) INCORRECT:

Immune complex deposition is characteristic of Henoch-Schonlein purpura (HSP), which is a small vessel vasculitis that can manifest with malaise, arthralgia, and cutaneous lesions. However, the cutaneous lesions of HSP are nontender palpable purpura rather than tender nodules (erythema nodosum). Moreover, decreased peripheral pulses and involvement of large vessels (e.g., aorta, brachial arteries) would not be expected. Instead, HSP manifests with other features, such as nephritic syndrome (due to IgA nephropathy) and abdominal pain.

E) INCORRECT:

Mönckeberg arteriosclerosis is characterized by calcification of the tunica media, and it is associated with diabetes mellitus. This condition usually affects the smaller vessels in the extremities and is not associated with stenosis. Furthermore, thickening of the aortic arch, erythema nodosum, and the systemic symptoms of night sweats, malaise, joint pain, and weight loss are not associated with Mönckeberg arteriosclerosis.
questions.hint: This patient's findings of weak peripheral pulses, carotid bruits, elevated ESR, and thickening of the aortic arch should raise concern for Takayasu arteritis. This type of large vessel vasculitis predominantly occurs in women under the age of 40 years (especially those with Asian ancestry).

questions.text:
A 22-year-old woman is hospitalized after experiencing fevers of unknown origin for 3 weeks. During the past week, she has also noted achiness in both arms that is precipitated by activity and resolves with rest. She denies other muscle or joint pain, rash, or any history of intravenous drug use. Her examination reveals diminished radial pulses in both hands without evidence of digital cyanosis.
Laboratory evaluation reveals negative blood cultures, a normal chest radiograph, and normal urinalysis findings — but an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 98 mm/hr (reference range, 1–25) and a C-reactive protein level of 35.0 mg/liter (0.08–3.10).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus and adult-onset Still disease do not cause large-vessel vasculitis. In addition, although adult-onset Still disease is associated with daily fevers, it is often associated with arthritis or arthralgias, an evanescent salmon-colored rash, and leukocytosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Giant-cell arteritis leads to large-vessel involvement that is indistinguishable from Takayasu arteritis in about 15% of cases, but giant-cell arteritis proven by temporal artery biopsy is essentially nonexistent in people younger than age 50.

C) CORRECT:

Takayasu arteritis, also known as “pulseless disease,” primarily affects women in early and middle adulthood, most often in the aorta and the proximal portions of its major branches. Active inflammatory disease is characterized by the development of new or worsening symptoms of vascular compromise and/or constitutional symptoms, such as fever, fatigue, and weight loss. Takayasu arteritis is usually a chronic or relapsing/remitting disease but can be monophasic. Symptoms of extremity claudication, dizziness, renovascular hypertension, and (less commonly) angina or symptoms of compromised blood flow to abdominal organs often persist once stenoses have developed.

Absent or diminished peripheral pulses or asymmetric blood-pressure measurements can suggest the diagnosis of Takayasu arteritis. Angiographic evidence of stenoses or (less commonly) aneurysms of large arteries confirms the diagnosis. Thickening of arterial walls without stenosis, as can be seen on MRI or CT but not conventional angiography, is suggestive of Takayasu but not completely specific, particularly if only the aorta is involved (“isolated aortitis”).

Key learning point: Absent or diminished peripheral pulses in a young woman with arm claudication and elevated inflammatory markers is suggestive of Takayasu arteritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly referred to as Churg-Strauss syndrome) is a vasculitis of small vessels and is characterized by asthma, rhinosinusitis, and peripheral eosinophilia.

E) INCORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus and adult-onset Still disease do not cause large-vessel vasculitis.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 23-year-old woman who works as a teacher reports several weeks of increasing difficulty with prolonged use of her hands, such as writing on the chalkboard, typing on her laptop, or blow-drying her hair. She describes a throbbing achiness in her hands and also reports a 4.5-kg unintentional weight loss during the past 6 months. She has no history of cigarette smoking.
She has a temperature of 37.8°C; her vital signs are otherwise normal. She has diminished radial and ulnar pulses bilaterally.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
9200
4500–11,000


Hematocrit (%)
30
36–46


Platelet count (per mm3)
300,000
150,000–350,000


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.0
0.6–1.1



Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (mm/hr)
102
1–25


Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cryoglobulinemia also involves small vessels and would not cause claudication.

B) INCORRECT:

Thromboangiitis obliterans affects medium and small vessels, occurs almost exclusively in smokers, involves the lower more than the upper extremities, and affects males more often than females. Patients most often present with distal-extremity ischemia or digit ischemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Giant-cell arteritis affects only patients older than age 50 and typically produces symptoms related to involvement of the cranial vasculature (extradural branches of the carotid arteries); extremity claudication due to subclavian and/or axillary artery involvement occurs in only 10% to 20% of patients.

D) INCORRECT:

Leukocytoclastic vasculitis is a small-vessel vasculitis and would not cause claudication.

E) CORRECT:

Takayasu arteritis is a rare vasculitis of the large arteries that typically affects young women. Common symptoms include constitutional symptoms, such as fever and weight loss, and localizing symptoms corresponding to the arteries involved: claudication in the upper or lower extremities, headache and other symptoms of severe hypertension due to renal-artery stenosis, dizziness, angina, and postprandial abdominal pain. Laboratory findings include elevated inflammatory markers and mild anemia.

Takayasu arteritis involves the aorta and its major branches. Subclavian stenosis, typical of Takayasu arteritis, should be visualized using CT or magnetic resonance angiography. In a young patient, the diagnosis is made by correlating the clinical presentation with typical radiographic features. In this population, vascular obstruction should not be confused with atherosclerotic disease. The mainstay of treatment is glucocorticoids, with other immunosuppressive drugs likely to have glucocorticoid-sparing benefit based on case series.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a young woman with no history of cigarette smoking who develops exertional symptoms in her arms, loses weight, and is found to have diminished forearm pulses and elevated inflammatory markers is Takayasu arteritis.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of progressively worsening joint pain. She describes diffuse, aching pain in her knees, shoulders, and hands bilaterally, which has become much more severe over the past few weeks. She also reports night sweats and generalized malaise. On examination, her radial pulses are weak. There are erythematous nodules measuring 3–5 cm over her legs. Laboratory studies show:


Hematocrit (Hct), blood
0.332 L/L (0.38–0.50)


Hemoglobin (Hgb), blood
107 g/L (115–155)


White blood cell (WBC) count, blood
11.3 × 109/L (3.5–10.5)


Platelet count, blood
615 × 109/L (130–380)


Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), blood

94 mm/h (0–20)


C-reactive protein, blood
400 mg/L (≤ 10)


Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Giant cell arteritis (GCT) is more common in women and can cause malaise, arthralgias, night sweats, decreased peripheral pulses, an elevated ESR, increased CRP, anemia, leukocytosis, and thrombocytosis. However, GCT is almost exclusively seen in patients above the age of 50 years, and cutaneous manifestations are not seen. Instead, patients typically have a history of headache, scalp pain, and jaw claudication because the temporal artery is frequently affected.

B) INCORRECT:

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) can manifest with erythematous nodules, malaise, night sweats, arthralgia, anemia, leukocytosis, and elevated ESR and CRP. However, decreased radial pulsations are typically not present because peripheral vascular disease is a rare manifestation of PAN. Instead, patients usually present with hypertension and/or renal insufficiency (due to renal artery stenosis) and symptoms of neuropathy (e.g., paresthesias, sensory loss, weakness).

C) CORRECT:

Takayasu arteritis is a granulomatous inflammation involving all layers of the walls of large arteries such as the aorta and its major branches. Its incidence peaks at 15–45 years of age and it is more common in women (especially those of Asian ethnicity). In the initial stages of the disease, patients have nonspecific symptoms such as fever, malaise, and/or arthralgia. Eventually, the large arteries narrow, which causes decreased peripheral pulses (so-called pulseless disease). Systemic inflammation causes elevation of ESR, CRP, leukocyte count, and thrombocyte count. In some patients, necrotizing inflammation of medium-sized subcutaneous vessels occurs, which results in erythema nodosum.

See “Overview of large-vessel vasculitides” table.

Key learning point: Takayasu arteritis is a large-vessel vasculitis in young women, presenting with systemic symptoms, diminished pulses, elevated inflammatory markers, and sometimes erythema nodosum.
Image Description:

MRI angiography aorta (A: with contrast; sagittal plane. B: inversion recovery dark blood sequence; axial plane)

The descending aorta shows luminal dilatation and irregularity (A: green overlay), with multiple areas of wall thickening (B: examples indicated by red dimension lines).

These features are characteristic of Takayasu arteritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Because thromboangiitis obliterans (TAO) causes endarteritis and occlusion of distal, medium-sized arteries, it could manifest in a young adult with decreased radial pulses. However, TAO is much more common in men, and features such as malaise, night sweats, arthralgia, erythematous nodules, a raised ESR, leukocytosis, and thrombocytosis would not be expected. Instead, a history of smoking, Raynaud phenomenon, and features of superficial thrombophlebitis (cord-like, painful veins) would be present.

E) INCORRECT:

Microscopic polyangiitis can cause malaise, arthralgias, night sweats, skin nodules, anemia, leukocytosis, thrombocytosis, and an elevated ESR and CRP. However, microscopic polyangiitis is usually seen in middle-aged adults. Furthermore, decreased peripheral pulses would not be expected because microscopic polyangiitis predominantly involves small arteries (arterioles). Instead, patients present with features of nephritic syndrome (e.g., hematuria, hypertension) and acute renal failure (e.g., oliguria) as a result of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, or hemoptysis due to alveolar hemorrhage.
questions.hint: Aortic arteriography of this patient would show areas of thickening and narrowing of the aortic arch.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 3-week history of fatigue, night sweats, and bilateral arm pain that worsens with movement. Vital signs show blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg in the left arm and 130/75 mmHg in the right arm. Physical examination shows weakly palpable bilateral radial pulses and bilateral carotid bruits. Laboratory studies show an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform urgent echocardiography to assess cardiac function
Order bilateral upper extremity arterial Doppler studies
Arrange for biopsy of the affected vessel

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High-dose glucocorticoids and methotrexate are part of the treatment for Takayasu arteritis, but the diagnosis should be confirmed before starting immunosuppressive therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography should be considered to assess for aortic regurgitation and ventricular hypertrophy in patients with Takayasu arteritis, but diagnostic confirmation is required first.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient's clinical presentation strongly suggests Takayasu arteritis, which requires rheumatology referral and diagnostic confirmation with imaging. MR angiography is the preferred initial study.

D) INCORRECT:

Upper extremity arterial Doppler studies do not provide the comprehensive evaluation of the aorta and major branches needed to diagnose large vessel vasculitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Biopsy of affected vessels is not routinely required for diagnosis but may be considered for patients with planned vascular interventions. Because affected vessels are often inaccessible, biopsy is not always possible, and diagnostic confirmation frequently relies on imaging. Furthermore, specialist consult is needed.
